lines.text: Do you know what the most frightening thing in the world is? It's fear.
Got a question for you. Which magazine sells the most copies?
Those with girls on the front covers and no front covers on the girls.
What would frighten me to death? Set the mood for me, Mark.
Imagine... someone coming towards you... who wants to kill you... regardless of the consequences.
A madman?
Yes. But he knows it - and you don't.
[Mark is about to be interviewed by the police and is filming their investigation]
Suppose they catch you?
Oh they will. They look very efficient.
Don't you mind?
No.
Mark, are you crazy?

[laughs]
Yes. Do you think they'll notice?
I visit this room every night.
Visit?
The blind always live in the rooms they live under.

[referring to Mark]
I don't trust a man who walks quietly.
He's shy.
His footsteps aren't. They're stealthy.

[an elderly customer has just hurried out of the shop after purchasing pornography and a daily newspaper]
Well, he won't be doing the crossword tonight.
[last lines]
Don't be a silly boy. There's nothing to be afraid of!

[Softly]
Good night Daddy. Hold my hand.
Helen?
Yes?
Doesn't matter.
Mother, what's worrying you?
The price of whiskey.
Instinct's a wonderful thing, isn't it, Mark? A pity *it* can't be photographed. If I'd listened to it years ago, I - I might have kept my sight. I wouldn't have let a man operate I had no faith in.
[first lines]
[Mark approaches the prostitute, covertly filming her]
It'll be two quid
The silly bitch! She's fainted in the wrong scene!
Whatever I photograph I always lose.
It's no good. The lights fade too soon
They always do.
I... I have to try again.
What do you think you've spoiled?
An opportunity. Now I have to find another one.
I like to understand what I'm shown.
Take me to your cinema.

[to Mark as he arrives]
Well if it isn't Cecil Beaton...
